Knowledge Point: In the non"=present imperfective -- Past Imperfective in (\ref{ex:11-1}) and Future in (\ref{ex:11-2}) --, the verb always agrees in person in accordance with an~accusative alignment, i.e., with the subject, whether S, as in the intransitive clause in (\ref{ex:11-1}), or A, as in the transitive clause in (\ref{ex:11-2}).
An accusative agreement pattern is also applied in the Present, as can be seen in examples (\ref{ex:11-3})--(\ref{ex:11-4}), although here in the form of number and gender agreement.

When, on the other hand, any of the TMA categories based on the perfective are used, the verb always agrees~-- in accordance with an~ergative alignment~-- with S, as in (\ref{ex:11-5}), or O as in (\ref{ex:11-6}) and (\ref{ex:11-7}), whereas it never agrees in gender and number with A.

Even when O occurs in a non"=nominative form (described in detail in \sectref{subsec:11-2-2}), as in (\ref{ex:11-7b}), the verb still agrees in gender and number with that particular noun phrase argument.

As we saw in \sectref{sec:4-5}, the central case distinction made inflectionally is that between the nominative and the oblique cases. As for the relations we are interested in, the nominative is used for S, A and O alike in the non"=perfective categories, whereas in the perfective, A, as in (\ref{ex:11-10}), is singled out as coded in the oblique case (kaṭamuš-á) versus the nominatively\footnote{In the description of a~system with a~consistently ergative case alignment, this would be referred to as absolutive, a~term I prefer not to use when describing the split ergative system of Palula.} coded (kaṭamúš) S in (\ref{ex:11-8}) and O in (\ref{ex:11-9}).

The noun phrase slot could of course also be filled with a~pronoun, and here too we have different forms bearing a~relation to case. Apart from the singling out of A in the perfective, asím in (\ref{ex:11-12}), we also have pronominal forms particular to O, asaám in (\ref{ex:11-13}), vis-à-vis S, be in (\ref{ex:11-11}) and A (in the perfective and the non"=perfective alike).
